column1: G100;By active we refer to an account that publishes new materials at least once a week. A social media presence may include a Facebook
column2: Twitter
column3: LinkedIn account that regularly published open data related content. Ideally a social media account would help promote the open data and more specific portal activities and increase visibility of the open data published on the national portal.

column4: use cases

column6: visits
column7: or use cases uploaded to the national portal referencing their data.

column1: G106;Please note that a regular updating of metadata refers here to an updating that is in line with the characteristics of the dataset in question. Different datasets have different requirements of currency. For example
column2: a gazetteer of city streets only changes when new buildings and roads are built
column3: or street names are changed
column4: whereas the data on current weather conditions may be updated in quasi-real time.

column1: G109;This applies both to individual datasets that change in time and to archives of the same dataset
column2: e.g. one every year
column3: every month etc. Administrative geography is an example of data that changes regularly. When new houses are built
column4: new postcodes may be created
column5: and the areas referred by pre-existing postcodes may change. Making available previous versions of a postcode reference file enables the reuser to correctly interpret the meaning of a postcode vs the relevant time context.

column2: adopted in December 2022 and published in January 2023 by the European Commission
column3: lays down a list of specific high-value datasets and the arrangements for their publication and re-use. https://eur-lex.europa.eu/legal-content/EN/TXT/?uri=CELEX%3A32023R0138

column1: G10b;Stakeholders could refer to open data reusers (business
column2: civil society) or other actors that might not be direct reusers of the data (e.g. engaged or interested citizens).

column3: lays down a list of specific high-value datasets and the arrangements for their publication and re-use. https://eur-lex.europa.eu/legal-content/EN/TXT/?uri=CELEX%3A32023R0138

column1: G111b;Such information can be made available as visualisations (e.g. the MQA tool of the EDP)
column2: or as downloadable file (ideally in .csv format) on the national portal.

column1: G112;Such guidelines can take the form of a document or tools (a licensing assistant) available on the national portal. An example of such tool is the data.europa.eu Licensing Assistant: https://data.europa.eu/en/training/licensing-assistant.

G118;Guidelines (check-lists) can enable publishers provide their data in open and machine-readable formats (.csv or .xml instead of proprietary non-machine-readable formats). Other tools can assist publishers to clean up the actual data (e.g. OpenRefine
column2: programming languages such as R).

column1: G119a;By ‘regularly’ we mean a bi-annual or at least annual frequency for activities such as e-learning modules and materials
column2: webinars
column3: meetings. Incentivisation can include the promotion of good quality datasets
column4: e.g. featuring them on the portal homepage
column5: showcasing the publishers as best practices at data providers’ events. Assistance can be provided through formal processes (e.g. data audits)
column6: training sessions with data providers
column7: other training and/or awareness raising activities (‘roadshows’) etc.

column1: G119b;By ‘high-quality metadata’ we refer to metadata that provides information in plain language – accurate
column2: current and complete
column3: on all DCAT-AP mandatory fields as well as relevant recommended and optional DCAT-AP fields.

column1: G11a;Please find for reference the European Commission´s priorities for 2019-2024: https://commission.europa.eu/strategy-and-policy/priorities-2019-2024_en
G11a1;Example: Green mobility has been prioritised as high-value dataset.

G11a2;Example 1: The strategy explores how open data can be used to foster the digitalisation of public services.                                                                                                                 Example 2: The strategy/policies foresee open data education projects to improve data literacy among citizens.
G11a3;Example: One of the objectives of my country´s open data policies/strategies is to create economic value by stimulating new buiness opportunities.
G11a4;Example: Gender inequality has been prioritised as high-value dataset.
G11a5;Example: Migration has been prioritised as high-value dataset.
G11a6;Example: One of the objectives of my country´s policies/strategies is to increase transparency and facilitate public participation in policy debates.

column2: increase transparency in public administrations.

the ‘download URL’ property contains a URL that is a direct link to a downloadable file in a given format.
the ‘access URL’ property contains a URL that gives access to a distribution of the dataset.
please visit: http://5stardata.info/en/ or https://joinup.ec.europa.eu/sites/default/files/inline-files/W3C04.pdf.

column1: G128b;"Refers to open data that is available on the web under an open licence
column2: in a structured format (=machine-readable format that is proprietary
column3: such as .xls; .xlsx). Please note that formats such as .pdf; .jpeg; .png
column4: .doc(x) are not considered machine-readable formats and should hence not be counted towards this answer."

column1: G128c;Refers to open data that is published in an open (=non-proprietary) machine-readable format. A non-proprietary format is a format for which a user does not require a proprietary software package (such as Microsoft Office Excel) to explore. An example of an open format is the comma-separated values (CSV) format for tabular data.
G128d;"Refers to open data whose comprising objects are accompanied by unique identifiers. An identifier may be the object’s name (e.g. city name ‘Luxembourg’
column2: or ‘10717’ -- a Berlin postcode)
column3: or a word describing the object (‘population’; ‘gender’)
column4: or another arbitrary identifier such as ‘XYZ0’
column5: an identifier that makes sense only in the context of that dataset. Choosing identifiers based on known standards should be the common practice though
column6: to facilitate data integration and linked data."

column2: strategies or portals that focus on the respective local/regional level.

column1: G2;The answer option 'Not applicable' can be selected if e.g. there is no specific strategy in place
column2: but the existing policy refers to the objectives
column3: actions/measures to be implemented
column4: delivery timelines
column5: responsible etc. Should another explanation apply in your case

column1: G40;"The governmental impact is hereby defined as the beneficial effect of the use of open data on three specific challenges faced by the government/public administrations: 1) Being efficient and effective in delivering public services; 2) Being transparent and accountable in their actions; 3) Improving their capacity to make decisions and policies."
G45;The social impact is hereby defined as the beneficial effect of the use of open data on four specific challenges for society: 1) Including minorities
column2: migrants
column3: and/or refugees  and reducing inequality
column4: 2) Alleviating housing issues
column6: 4) Improving education.

column1: G50;The environmental impact is hereby defined as the beneficial effect of the use of open data on four specific challenges connected to the environment: 1) Protecting biodiversity (e.g. maintaining a good level of air and water quality)
column2: 2) Achieving more environmental-friendly cities (e.g. in terms of transport and waste management)
column3: 3) Fighting climate change and connected disasters
column4: 4) Increasing the use of renewable sources of energy.
